titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the H.H. Seabrook papers 1980.036
titlestmt.author: Matthew Gorham
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was originally processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-07-09 20:55:30 +0000.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.abstract: The H.H. Seabrook papers primarily consist of receipts for purchases of goods and services from New York businesses by Henry Hendrickson Seabrook of New Jersey. The collection also includes photocopied genealogical notes that include references to members of the Conover family.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Barbara Epperson, date unknown. The papers were formally accessioned in 1980.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This small collection is housed in one folder and arranged in chronological order.

bioghist.head: Biographical note
bioghist.p: Henry Hendrickson Seabrook was born in 1813 and died in 1872. He was from New Jersey and seems to have lived there all or most of his life, but according to the documents in this collection, he did business in New York City.
Seabrook's daughter Annie Longstreet Seabrook married William L. Conover in 1877. They lived in Brooklyn.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); H.H. Seabrook papers, 1980.036, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Public Library, Center for Brooklyn History.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was rehoused and the finding aid revised by Dee Bowers in 2024.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Teunis G. Bergen and Bergen family collection (ARC.006)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The H.H. Seabrook papers primarily consist of receipts for purchases of goods and services from New York businesses by Henry Hendrickson Seabrook of New Jersey. Some of the receipts are made out to the owners of various steamships, which apparently included Seabrook. These include the steamer Only Son, steamship Westpoint, and steamer Keyport.
The collection also includes photocopied genealogical notes that include references to members of the Conover family and a clipping related to New York's water supply.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The materials in this collection are in the public domain. While many items at the Center for Brooklyn History are unrestricted, we do not own reproduction rights to all materials. Be aware of the several kinds of rights that might apply: copyright, licensing and trademarks. The researcher assumes all responsibility for copyright questions.
